mepHeader.prepDate: 2015-07-02 EK correct proof and update index

titlePart.supplied: Interview with the Brooklyn Daily Eagle

sourceDesc.bibl: 'Wide Open Again' Says Mrs. Sanger; Defies the Police, Brooklyn Daily Eagle, Nov. 13, 1916, p. 3

docBody.head: "WIDE OPEN AGAIN" SAYS MRS. SANGER; DEFIES THE POLICE

p.q: Mrs. Margaret Sanger, the birth-control champion, who was arrested for a violation of the Penal law in that she imparted birth-control knowledge to women, and whose case has not yet been disposed of, bade defiance to the police and Section 1142 of the Penal law today by reopening her clinic at 46 Amboy Street. Mrs. Sanger is out on bail and now awaits trial in the Court of Special Sessions. Her defense is that any law forbidding the imparting of 0 information on the subject of birth control is unconstitutional. So far, the District Attorney's office has not specified whether she is under arrest on a charge of violating Section 1142 of the Penal law or not. The failure to do so before Magistrate Steers in the New Jersey avenue court, and later in the Adams street court, resulted in several bitter arguments between Assistant District Attorney Kellogg and Jonah J. Goldstein, her counsel. As yet the section violated has not been specified and she is held simply on information.
She received twelve visitors today between the hours of 11 and 12. She opened her clinic at 10 o'clock, but it required an hour, she said, for the information to spread through Brownsville.

docBody.p: "I am back again," she said to an Eagle man and she smiled as she said it. "They may arrest me any moment, but what is the use. I shall return to this place and openly carry out the purpose of my clinic. That law is unconstitutional. The poor women of Brownsville need me. The poor women of Greater New York and the United States need me. I am only Margaret Sanger, but someone is destined to find out that Margaret Sanger will not be frightened off. They will also learn that a woman fighting for what she believes and knows is right does not know the meaning of fear or defeat."

"The Raymond Street Jail, with its varied assortment of weird and awesome vermin, I'll admit, is enough to frighten anyone, but my mission and my work can even bid defiance to seven Raymond street jails."

p.q: "What are you doing here this morning?" was asked.

docBody.p: "Doing? What would you suppose I am doing. I am giving the women who come to my place the information they desire--the information they need."

"You may say for me that I intend to stay here as long as the police will let me. If they take me out, it will be under arrest and against my protest. When I regain my liberty, I will come right back. That is Margaret Sanger's message to the thousands of women who need her."

p.q: Although she is back in her clinic, and admits she has again violated the law, conditions are somewhat changed. The police have confiscated the various things she had in the clinic before her arrest. Conditions also differ in that, today, the front door, previously unlatched and smooth-moving on its well-oiled hinges, is locked. To enter the women go in through the hall at the side and gain entrance to the clinic through a side door. Asked if this was a precaution against a sudden raid, Mrs. Sanger, said Miss Fannie Mindell, her assistant, had gone to the printers to order some hand bills and signs inviting the women of the section to come to the clinic, and there register their protest against Section 1142, and that she had carelessly locked the door--from outside.

When it was called to her attention that Miss Mindell did not look as though she needed a guardian to keep her from doing needless things and was not at all absent-minded, she laughed and declared she had given her reason for having the side door locked.

Officially, the Eleventh Inspection District and Inspector McElroy did not know the clinic was again in operation. A man who said he was Lieutenant Kelly declared he had no record of the clinic being open and that Inspector McElroy was out on a tour of the district.

However, Detective Boylan, who figured in the arrest with Sergeant Barry and Mrs. Margaret Whithurst, knew all about it. Boylan called at the clinic shortly before 12 o'clock. He did not appear at ease, Mrs. Sanger said.
"Are you at it again, Mrs. Sanger?"

docBody.p: "What does this look like?" was her questioning reply.
"What do you think?" responded Mrs. Sanger. "I am here--wide open and intend to remain here as long as I can."

p.q: gasped Boylan as he backed out of the place.

The district attorney's office would make no comment today beyond saying that the matter was entirely up to the police. Jonah J. Goldstein, counsel for Mrs. Sanger, did not know she had resumed operations until informed by The Eagle man.
"Well I'll be ---. You have to admire that woman's pluck. She did not consult me,"

"I presume she believes the law is unconstitutional and intends to go right on with her work. My job is to show the unconstitutionality of the law and that I will do if I possibly can. Mrs. Sanger is a woman of great determination. She believes in herself. Say, don't you admire her grit? Open again. Well, I'll be ---. Open again."
